discourse_list.title: [\xf0\x9f\x93\x84] Collateral Onboarding Call #22: People's Company - Wednesday, January 6th 18:00 UTC

content.content: collateral221280×720 63.5 KB  Join us on an epiphany while we kick-start the year with another call on the supply-side of Dai. Time in your local-timezone format: 2021-01-06T18:00:00Z  Dial In Details Zoom Call Passcode: RWA-WG  Intro An open discussion where we discuss projects and potential assets for MCD, open for anyone to join. If you’d like to present, check out this thread  Agenda  Intro by  @juanjuan  RWA Working Group Comment by @sebventures  Year Kick-off Summary Next steps   Centrifuge - Quick Intro by @_LS  People’s Company (https://peoplescompany.com/)  MIP6: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/p1-drop-mip6-application-peoples-company-drop-us-agricultural-real-estate/5518   See you there! attn: @amyjung; @blimpa ; @williamr ;  @spin ; @Deimos ; @Primoz  ; @mrabino1

Collateral Call Summary - Episode #22  January 6th, 2021 Agenda   00:00: Intro with Juan Guillén  00:01: Peoples Company with Mark Moore, Dave Muth, Steve Bruere and Bruce Sherrick  52:37: Q&A and Discussion about Peoples Company  01:00:46: Outro  Video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mQeb6Pi5YDM Introduction Juan Guillén Agenda and Preamble 00:00  Welcome to another MakerDAO collateral call. Today we are having a RWA collateral call. One of the projects that joined us very briefly last year is going to present again so we can go more in detail into the project, how it works and how the interaction with MakerDAO would work. This company is Peoples Company (website). Discussions about collateral happen in the Forum.   Peoples Company  [P1-DROP] MIP6 Application: Peoples Company DROP: US Agricultural Real Estate  Mark Moore, Dave Muth, Steve Bruere and Bruce Sherrick Presentation 00:01 DROP tokens backed by U.S. farmland1920×1080 146 KB Roster1920×1080 145 KB Discussion summary1920×1080 174 KB Overview1920×1080 187 KB Current state of the U.S. farmland asset class1920×1080 65.8 KB 09:11 — Juan Guillén: Going back to the previous slide, if Maker or anyone gives you 10M or 20M Dai, does that go to one of those activities that were listed or is it on this specific case? U.S. AG sector balance sheet1920×1080 188 KB Conclusions1920×1080 175 KB Farmland returns in context 01920×1080 201 KB Farmland investment growth1920×1080 132 KB Farmland returns in context 11920×1080 173 KB U.S. farmland returns1920×1080 203 KB Appropriate discount rate for farmland1920×1080 150 KB AEA farmland investement services and strategies1920×1080 74.1 KB 17:59 — planet_x: Regarding subsidies and political risk, how large are U.S. subsidies? Could cut in subsidies impact the price of farmland? 21:53 — Prose: I was curious how it will work with the actual collateralizing process with Maker. Are these lands that individuls would go through Peoples’? Or are people looking to buy slices of a project already purchased? AEA overview1920×1080 189 KB AEA competitive advantage1920×1080 162 KB AEA investment services1920×1080 147 KB U.S. farmland asset class1920×1080 232 KB Opportunities in focus1920×1080 157 KB Shifting consumer trends1920×1080 269 KB Demand for sustainability1920×1080 263 KB Financialization1920×1080 135 KB Technology1920×1080 238 KB Food supply chain1920×1080 130 KB Comprehensive asset management1920×1080 216 KB Asset management - Structures1920×1080 197 KB Asset management - Execution1920×1080 177 KB Asset management - Sustainability1920×1080 160 KB Customized investment strategies1920×1080 157 KB Case study - conventional row crop improvement1920×1080 183 KB Case study - organic transition lease1920×1080 161 KB Applications of the facility1920×1080 279 KB Terms1920×1080 119 KB Table1920×1080 245 KB Thank you1920×1080 135 KB Discussion  52:37 — Frank Cruz: A quick question with regards to the risk and with regards to farm sector solvency ratios: can you give us an idea if they’re even or they’re down for the last 10 years? 54:19 — Frank Cruz: Just to compare with 2008, would you say it’s about the same or a little bit lower currently? 55:18 — Free discussion with Sébastien Derivaux 58:56 — Frank Cruz: If 80% of the farmers are over 55 years of age, who’s going to be taking over the farming in 20 years, in your opinion?  Closing Comment Juan Guillén Outro 01:00:46  Thank you, Mark, Steven, Dave, Bruce from Peoples Company for presenting the project. Very interesting. We’ll see you in the forum. Before we leave, can you tell how people can find more about your project and where to find you personally? (01:00:56)  Thank you for joining. Next week we’ll have the xDai team coming to present the Stake application. We’ll also have Patricio from the POAP —Proof of Attendance Protocol— as a special guest.  Credits   @blimpa produced this summary. Everyone who spoke and presented on the call, listed in the headers.
@juan it would be great if you can add a “google calendar” link to all call. Edit : ICS link, I guess.

alexis:  “google calendar” link to all call. Edit : ICS link, I guess.   Hi, Alexis. @amyjung is maintaining a Google Calendar (not sure if this duty can be shared in the future). I added to my own calendar and cannot remember how to do it (or get the link). I’ve screamed a couple times at the UI/UX to no avail. I try to keep this table updated with the upcoming (and past) calls, although I understand that it’s less ideal. I also pin the topic to the forum (first locally and globally on the same day). Maybe there’s an easy way of converting one of these into an ics file. I’ll try to research something. TL;DR: maintaining this over different channels is not ideal.

I don’t think you need a calendar. it is just a link to add. You should be able to click right on your event and option then you should have something like publish event. From google doc the second option is the one you want for your personal calendar and the first option is the one @amyjung probably want for her page : Add a Google calendar to your website You can add an interactive version of your calendar to your website, and add buttons for your website visitors to save your calendar events. Embed a calendar on your website  On a computer, open Google Calendar. You can only get the code to embed in your website from a computer, not the Google Calendar app. In the top right, click Settings   Settings. On the left side of the screen, click the name of the calendar you want to embed. In the “Integrate calendar” section, copy the iframe code displayed. Under the embed code, click Customize.  Choose your options, then copy the HTML code displayed.  Your embedded calendar will only be visible to people you’ve shared it with. To allow all visitors to see your calendar, you’ll need to make it public. Let site visitors save a calendar event You can add a Google Calendar button to your website so visitors can quickly save your event on their own Google Calendars. To let anyone save your calendar event, you’ll need to make your calendar public.  On a computer, open Google Calendar. You can only make changes to your calendar visibility from a computer, not the mobile app. On a public calendar, create or edit an event. Click More actions  Publish event  In the “Publish event” window, copy the HTML code displayed. Open your website editor, then paste this code where you want the event button to display.

Hi all, @juan you can add a link to the global calendar as seen on the G&R Meeting Posts. From the global calendar, anyone can click the bottom right hand “+ Google Calendar” and add it directly to their calendar (unfortunately only Google calendar). A more UX friendly one was a request and we’ve looked into a few already, but it’s been pretty low in our priority list. Or you can add the Google Calendar directly using this link: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/0?cid=bWFrZXJkYW8uY29tXzNlZmhtMmdoaXBrc2VnbDAwOWt0bmlvbWRrQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20
Now grow food for the homeless and people that can’t afford it?  What are the land management goals?  We should work toward soil quality at the least.
